proof:
Proof. Let $C_1, \dots, C_k$ be components of $(V_H, E_H \setminus E')$ and wlog $C_1$ is the component of the highest total degree.
Case 1. $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) < \frac{\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)}{2}$. Then for all $1 \le i \le k$, $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_i) < \frac{\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)}{2}$, and hence by Proposition 44 to get $|E'| \ge \sum_{i=1}^k \alpha \mathrm{deg}_H(C_i) = \alpha|E_H|$. However, $|E'| \le \theta|E_H| \le \alpha|E_H|$. Contradiction, this case cannot happen.
Case 2. $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) \ge \frac{\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)}{2}$. Then it follows $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k) \le \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)/2$, and thus we can use the third expansion property to get
$$ |E'| \ge \alpha \mathrm{deg}_H(C_2 \cup \dots \cup C_k) = \alpha(\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H) - \mathrm{deg}_H(C_1)) $$
This gives $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) \ge \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H) - |E'|/\alpha$. Since the total degree of a set is proportional to its number of edges, we can relate $|E'|$ to $|E_H|$ by the ratio of their volumes, yielding $|E'| < \theta |E_H| \frac{\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)}{\mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)} = \theta \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)$. This gives $\mathrm{deg}_H(C_1) \ge \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H) - \theta \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)/\alpha = (1 - \frac{\theta}{\alpha}) \mathrm{deg}_H(V_H)$.
